notes:
1. Unified Soil Classification System (USCS)

The USCS is the most common system used by geotechnical engineers. It classifies soils into two main categories based on the percentage passing the No. 200 sieve (0.075 mm):

  • Coarse-Grained Soils: More than 50% retained on the No. 200 sieve. Subdivided into Gravels (G) and Sands (S). Further classified by gradation (Well-graded W, Poorly-graded P) or fines content (Silty M, Clayey C).
  • Fine-Grained Soils: 50% or more passes the No. 200 sieve. Subdivided into Silts (M) and Clays (C) based on the Atterberg limits. Further classified by compressibility (Low Liquid Limit L, High Liquid Limit H).

2. The Plasticity Chart

Fine-grained soils are classified using the Plasticity Chart, which plots Plasticity Index (PI) vs. Liquid Limit (LL). The A-line separates clays from silts.

Equation of the A-line: $PI = 0.73(LL - 20)$

  • Above the A-line: Clay (C)
  • Below the A-line: Silt (M) or Organic (O)
  • LL < 50: Low Plasticity (L)
  • LL $\ge$ 50: High Plasticity (H)

3. AASHTO Classification System

Used primarily for highway construction. Soils are classified into seven groups, A-1 through A-7, based on grain size and Atterberg limits. A-1 is the best subgrade material (gravel/sand), while A-7 is the poorest (clay).

solvedExamples.question: A fine-grained soil has a Liquid Limit of 50 and a Plastic Limit of 20. Using the USCS, what is its classification?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the Plasticity Index: $PI = LL - PL = 50 - 20 = 30$. Since $LL \ge 50$, it is a high plasticity soil (H). Next, check the A-line: $PI_{A-line} = 0.73(LL - 20) = 0.73(50 - 20) = 0.73(30) = 21.9$. The soil's PI (30) is greater than the A-line PI (21.9), so it plots above the A-line, making it a Clay (C). Therefore, the classification is CH (Fat Clay).

solvedExamples.question: In the USCS, a soil is classified as a sand (S) if:

options.text: More than 50% passes the No. 200 sieve.
More than 50% is retained on the No. 200 sieve, and the coarse fraction is mostly smaller than the No. 4 sieve.
More than 50% is retained on the No. 200 sieve, and the coarse fraction is mostly larger than the No. 4 sieve.

solvedExamples.explanation: First, the soil must be coarse-grained (>50% retained on No. 200). Then, to be a sand, the sand fraction (passing No. 4 but retained on No. 200) must be greater than the gravel fraction (retained on No. 4).
